The street style trends you can (and should) steal from the guys outside fashion shows

Every year, the best-dressed guys of the world attend fashion week, and every year, we pick their pockets for some inspo
By Mahalia Chang
9 October 2024

    All products are independently selected by our editors. If you buy something, we may earn an affiliate commission.

    Street style trends are a sleeper assassin in the world of dressing inspiration. Of course, fashion month is blessed ground for a number of reasons. Itâs where you see what trends and which clothing pieces will reign for the season, the creative directors of the worldâs fashion houses cooking up the future in their labs. It also provides us with solid Hollywood fits from the top dogs who show out for their favourite labels.

    But things are just as interesting outside the shows. On the pavements of Milan, Paris, New York and London, street style photographers are trained to capture editors, influencers and show-goers whose influence has gotten them an invite.

    So while whatâs on the runways might give you a cue as to what youâre going to wear in six months, the guests have what you should be wearing right now.

    Below, the biggest street style trends to steal from some of the best-dressed guys around the world.

    Varsity jackets

    Let it be said, American colleges get two things very right: tailgate parties and varsity jackets. This season, the circles of casual outerwear and sportswear crossed over in the Venn diagram of good jackets, leading to a field rush of varsity jackets.

    Alongside patch-adorned, shiny classic versions, proper menswear-ified takes were also out and about, courtesy of Louis Vuitton and Lacoste. The good news is that the rise in popularity has also meant a rise in options. Now, in addition to the traditional knit stand-up collar, you can also find button-collar versions; as well as every crop and colour under the sun; versions both plain, and embellished like crazy.

    For more polish, swap out the blazer and wear your varsity jacket over a shirt and tie. Casual loyalists should keep things simple and layer it over a hoodie or a T-shirt, with a crossbody bag. Go sports.

    New (old) denim

    Donât panic: classic denim is unlikely to ever go out of style. But in the past couple of seasons, there has been something of a shift. Itâs like if classic denim went through a bit of a midlife crisis and bought a shiny red Porsche to make him feel alive. The bones of classic denim are still there â a deep indigo blue, straight-leg cut, belt loops exactly where you left them â but thereâs been a few fun changes for some new life.

    Joe Alwyn hit the JW Anderson show in London wearing a pair of chopped and screwed jeans, the back pocket stitched the front, the seams criss-crossing. Other attendees in Milan and Paris went for all-over prints or embellishments. Embroidery, patches, stepped hems and wacky dye washes are all on the menu.

    But denimâs new look shouldnât scare you. The trick is to style it exactly as you would your regular. A good tee, a slim sneaker, your best jacket, the Porsche parked in the driveway. Oh, this old thing? Just fancied a new ride. You know how it is.

    Mixed suiting

    The full suit can be intimidating. For those who wear it daily for work, it veers too far into the uniform lane. And for those whose suits are reserved for weddings and funerals, it feels too formal. Thankfully, the street style guys are helpfully modelling the blessed alternative: mixed suiting. By mixing suiting separates together â as in, wearing a trouser with a blazer, both of a different colour, fabric or pattern â it not only takes the sting of the suit, making it feel more casual and irreverent, but it also adds some depth to one of menswearâs oldest guards.

    Keep things neutral in blacks, greys, creams and browns, but mix it up from there. If you donât feel like going for two completely different coloured items, switching up the pattern or fabric can do the trick, too. A slick pair of glasses and a shiny loafer brings things home.

    In the trenches

    Within the well-warmed universe of outerwear, the overcoat has reigned for too long. Understandably, of course; the big wool overcoat has served us faithfully through many blustery afternoons and frosty mornings. Let its service not be forgotten. But the turn of the season means it is time for something new, and the boys at the shows have been making a fascinating case for the trench coat.

    In a parade of neutral shades, from taupe to beige and tan, a long, sweepy trench was a go-to pick for show-goers in Milan and Paris. Slightly oversized to hang off the shoulders, and hitting around mid-calf for maximum petulant swish, trenches were worn with everything from formal fits with shiny Oxfords, and casual looks with clashing colour.

    A hint of red

    Earlier this year, the girls coined the âpop of redâ theory when it came to outfits. That being: adding a little touch of bright red to any fit looks intentional, fun and dynamic. And while the guys were slightly slower on the draw, there's a few red alerts to follow.

    For some, a bright red cap was key to levelling up a classic formula. On others, we saw red sneakers soup up a trousers-and-tee combo, and a little red sweater peeking out from under an anorak. Luckily, this trend is easy (and fun) to pull off: put together your go-to look and then add a hint of red somewhere super subtle. Hats are great options, as are scarves, shoes and bags. Want to go even subtler? Add a bright red sock under your trouser leg.

    Sports jerseys have been big in the fashion realm for a while now. For the footballheads living among us (and for the merch-as-fashion crowd, too), that trend continues. Long live blokecore. But if youâre keen to level it up a touch, well-dressed guys in New York and Paris were evolving the trend for the good of mankind.

    There are two pathways to upgrade: one, to opt for merch from a non-obvious sport. Football and basketball jerseys have done the dance, whereas NFL and baseball jerseys were all over New York. In Paris, the second option was hot: fashion pieces inspired by sports codes, including Louis Vuittonâs take on a football shirt, and New Eraâs football-jersey version of a Lakers top. Just donât wear it with any other merch, or the sportswear multiverse will collapse in on itself.

    Big bad cargo shorts

    If you thought, just because itâs cold out, that shorts season was over, youâre in for a treat. Cargo shorts, the pocketed, hiking boyfriend of the trousers world, came up clutch during fashion month. Worn with tall socks and warmer layers like jackets and knitwear for the nippier days, and with button-down shirts and caps for when the sun was making a rare appearance, they proved to be a versatile and easy building block for a host of good outfits.

    Taking cues from the crowd, it seemed like a longer, over-the-knee cut and baggier fit were key components, while neutral shades of brown and beige kept them classic. The more pockets, the better.

    A little neckerchief

    What do cowboys and well-dressed editors at fashion shows have in common? No, it isnât reminding competitors that âthis town isnât big enough for the both of us.â Itâs a love of a little neckscarf. At Pitti Uomo and in Milan, we spotted cotton bandanas wound around the necks of show goers, peeking out from under suits and over cotton T-shirts. Itâs a low-effort, high-impact styling choice, and one that can be customised infinitely â opt for a bright pop of colour (red, if you want to double-dip your trends!) to add dimension to a low-key look.

    In Florence for Pitti, scarves under open shirts and jackets was the ticket, while the Milanese crowd tucked them into knit polos. Whichever way you choose, we advise steering clear of chaps.
